prompt.role: You are an expert hepatologist creating Script Concordance Test (SCT) items. Generate ONE vignette with THREE independent questions (Diagnosis, Management, Follow-up).

sct_fundamentals.purpose: The SCT assesses clinical reasoning in uncertainty—particularly suited to hepatology where diagnostic dilemmas, management complexities, and follow-up controversies defy simple algorithms.

structure.vignette: Clinical scenario presenting an "ill-defined" problem with controlled ambiguity
structure.questions: THREE mandatory independent questions, each with: - Part A: Hypothesis/option ("If you were thinking of...") - Part B: New information ("...and then you find...") - Part C: 5-point Likert scale (effect on hypothesis)
structure.independence_rule: CRITICAL: Each question is INDEPENDENT. New information in Q1 does NOT carry to Q2 or Q3.

clinical_themes.theme: Navigating conflicting/incomplete data (e.g., positive serology with normal biopsy, seronegative villous atrophy, IgA deficiency pitfalls)
When standard care fails (e.g., non-responsive disease, refractory conditions, co-existing disorders, advanced therapies)
Monitoring without consensus (e.g., assessing adherence, role/timing of repeat procedures, structuring long-term care)

vignette_requirements.length: 120-240 words (COUNT CAREFULLY - strictly enforced; aim for 150-200)
vignette_requirements.content: - Patient demographics + medical history - Presenting symptoms + initial test results - Clinical context with controlled ambiguity - Plausible lab values, imaging, endoscopy findings
vignette_requirements.avoid: Deterministic clues, superfluous information, overly simplistic presentations

question_requirements.hypothesis: 8-25 words (Part A: "If you were thinking of...")
question_requirements.author_notes: Max 3 sentences, max 300 characters - explain clinical reasoning

antipatterns.avoid: Deterministic vignettes, double hypotheses, wrong Likert scales, dependencies between questions, author_notes >3 sentences or >300 chars

likert_scales.diagnosis: -2: Very unlikely/Ruled out | -1: Less likely | 0: No change | +1: More likely | +2: Very likely/Confirmed
likert_scales.management: -2: Strongly contraindicated | -1: Less indicated | 0: No change | +1: Indicated | +2: Strongly indicated/Essential
likert_scales.follow_up: -2: Very inappropriate | -1: Less appropriate | 0: No change | +1: Appropriate | +2: Essential/Standard

critical_requirements.requirement: 3 questions: Diagnostic, Management, Follow-up (in that order)

prompt.options_warning: ⚠️ CRITICAL: "options" field MUST be EXACTLY: ["+2", "+1", "0", "-1", "-2"] DO NOT use descriptive text. These are FIXED scale values. WRONG: ["Very likely", "Likely", ...] CORRECT: ["+2", "+1", "0", "-1", "-2"]

example.title: Seronegative Villous Atrophy (Diagnostic Dilemma)
example.vignette: A 68-year-old woman with a history of hypertension treated with olmesartan for the past 5 years presents with a 9-month history of non-bloody diarrhea (4-6 bowel movements per day), progressive fatigue, and an unintentional 10 kg weight loss. She reports no fever, night sweats, or family history of celiac disease or inflammatory bowel disease. Her medications include olmesartan 40 mg daily and atorvastatin 20 mg daily. Laboratory tests reveal iron deficiency anemia with a hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dL (normal 12-16 g/dL), ferritin 8 ng/mL (normal 15-150 ng/mL), and albumin 3.2 g/dL (normal 3.5-5.0 g/dL). Her IgA tissue transglutaminase (tTG) is 8 U/mL (normal <10 U/mL) and total IgA is 180 mg/dL (normal 70-400 mg/dL). An upper endoscopy reveals scalloping of the duodenal folds and mosaic pattern of the mucosa. Duodenal biopsies demonstrate Marsh 3c villous atrophy with increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. She is concerned about the findings and their implications.

question1.hypothesis: a diagnosis of seronegative celiac disease (SNCD)
question1.new_info: HLA testing is negative for both DQ2 and DQ8
question1.scale_anchors: [-2: Very unlikely/Ruled out | -1: Less likely | 0: No change | +1: More likely | +2: Very likely/Confirmed]
question1.author_notes: Negative HLA-DQ2/DQ8 essentially rules out celiac disease (>99% sensitivity). This makes SNCD very unlikely.

question2.hypothesis: immediately starting a strict gluten-free diet
question2.new_info: the patient's hypertension is well-controlled on her current regimen
question2.scale_anchors: [-2: Strongly contraindicated | -1: Less indicated | 0: No change | +1: Indicated | +2: Strongly indicated/Essential]
question2.author_notes: Olmesartan is a known cause of drug-induced enteropathy mimicking celiac disease. If hypertension control is adequate, switching medications is a reasonable diagnostic and therapeutic step before committing to a GFD.

question3.hypothesis: scheduling a repeat endoscopy in 6 months to assess histologic response
question3.new_info: you have substituted her olmesartan with another class of antihypertensive
question3.scale_anchors: [-2: Very inappropriate | -1: Less appropriate | 0: No change | +1: Appropriate | +2: Essential/Standard]
question3.author_notes: Switching from olmesartan makes reassessment highly appropriate to determine if enteropathy resolves without the drug. This supports follow-up endoscopy.

example.note: Each question is INDEPENDENT. New information in Q1, Q2, Q3 does not carry over between questions.
